In the boundary-state approach, the Hilbert space admits two factorizations for a single interval, producing distinct entanglement spectra determined by spin structures. Although R\'enyi and relative entropies are shown to be insensitive to these structures, symmetry-resolved entanglement naturally reveals their differences. The Majorana fermion's $\mathbb{Z}_2^F$ symmetry, generated by the fermion-parity operator $(-1)^F$, distinguishes bosonic from fermionic sectors, motivating the notion of fermion-parity resolution. While $\mathbb{Z}_2^F$ is naturally a symmetry of the vacuum and fermion reduced density matrices, the Hilbert space factorization is shown to stabilize this symmetry in conformal interface states. When an unpaired Majorana zero mode is present, fermion-parity-resolved entropies display equipartition at all orders in the UV cutoff; in its absence, the breaking of equipartition is quantified by Ramond-sector data. This behavior persists across all states considered. Connections with symmetry-protected topological phases of matter are outlined. All results are compared with twist field computations.

items.title: Entanglement Sum Rule from Higher-Form Symmetries
items.summary: -cross Abstract: We prove an entanglement sum rule for $(d-1)$-dimensional quantum lattice models with finite abelian higher-form symmetries, obtained by minimally coupling a sector on $p$-simplices carrying a $p$-form $G$ symmetry to a sector on $(p+1)$-simplices carrying the dual $(d-p-2)$-form $\widehat G$ symmetry (with $\widehat G$ being the Pontryagin dual of $G$). The coupling is introduced by conjugation with a symmetry-preserving operator $\mathcal{U}$ that dresses symmetry-invariant operators with appropriate Wilson operators. Our main result concerns symmetric eigenstates of the coupled model that arise by acting with $\mathcal{U}$ on direct-product symmetric eigenstates of the decoupled model: provided a topological criterion formulated via the Mayer--Vietoris sequence holds for the chosen bipartition, $\mathcal{U}$ factorizes across the cut when acting on the symmetric state, and the entanglement entropy equals the sum of the entropies of the two sectors. This framework explains and generalizes known examples in fermion-$\mathbb{Z}_2$ gauge theory, identifies when topology obstructs the sum rule, and provides a procedure to construct new examples by gauging higher-form symmetries.

items.title: A Remarkable Application of Zassenhaus Formula to Strongly Correlated Electron Systems
items.summary: -cross Abstract: We show that the Zassenhaus decomposition for the exponential of the sum of two non-commuting operators, simplifies drastically when these operators satisfy a simple condition, called the no-mixed adjoint property. An important application to a Unitary Coupled Cluster method for strongly correlated electron systems is presented. This ansatz requires no Trotterization and is exact on a quantum computer with a finite number of Givens gate equals to the number of free parameters. The formulas obtained in this work also shed light on why and when optimization after Trotterization gives exact solutions in disentangled forms of unitary coupled cluster.

items.title: Initial-State Typicality in Quantum Relaxation
items.summary: -cross Abstract: Relaxation in open quantum systems is fundamental to quantum science and technologies. Yet, the influence of the initial state on relaxation remains a central, largely unanswered question. Here, by systematically characterizing the relaxation behavior of generic initial states, we uncover a typicality phenomenon in high-dimensional open quantum systems: relaxation becomes nearly initial-state-independent as system size increases under verifiable conditions. Crucially, we prove this typicality for thermalization processes above a size-independent temperature. Our findings extend the typicality to open quantum dynamics, in turn identifying a class of systems where two widely used quantities -- the Liouvillian gap and the maximal relaxation time -- merit re-examination. We formalize this with two new concepts: the 'typical strong Mpemba effect' and the 'typical relaxation time'. Beyond these conceptual advances, our results provide practical implications: a scalable route to accelerating relaxation and a typical mixing-time benchmark that complements conventional worst-case metrics for quantum simulations and state preparation.

items.title: Two variants of the friendship paradox: The condition for inequality between them
items.summary: -cross Abstract: The friendship paradox -- the observation that, on average, one's friends have more friends than oneself -- admits two common formulations depending on whether averaging is performed over edges or over nodes. These two definitions, the "alter-based" and "ego-based" means, are often treated as distinct but related quantities. This paper establishes their exact analytical relationship, showing that the difference between them is governed by the degree-degree covariance normalized by the mean degree. Explicit examples demonstrate the three possible cases of positive, zero, and negative covariance, corresponding respectively to assortative, neutral, and disassortative mixing patterns. The derivation further connects the covariance form to the moment-based expression introduced by Kumar, Krackhardt, and Feld [Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 121, e2306412121 (2024)], which involves the (-1)st, 1st, 2nd, and 3rd moments of the degree distribution. The two formulations are shown to be equivalent, as they should be: the moment-based representation expands the same structural dependence that the covariance form expresses in its most compact and interpretable form. The analysis thus unifies node-level and moment-level perspectives on the friendship paradox, offering both a pedagogically transparent derivation and a direct bridge to recent theoretical developments.

items.title: Spatial fibroblast niches define Crohns fistulae

items.title: Florigen activation complex forms via multifaceted assembly in Arabidopsis
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09704-6 In flowering plants, DNAFD14-3-3 recruits FT to the florigen activation complex both through DNAFT interactions and by reducing liquid phase condensation of FD protein, which promotes dimerization, leading to FT recruitment.

items.title: The contribution of rock strength to soil production
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09751-z Findings from a tectonically active mountain range show that soil production is driven by bottom-up rock weakening rather than by soil thickness, challenging long-held top-down models.

items.title: Mortality impacts of rainfall and sea-level rise in a developing megacity
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09730-4 High-resolution rainfall, tide and mortaility data are used to quantify the impact of rainfall and flooding on urban health in Mumbai, India, revealing an order-of-magnitude discrepency between observed and officially reported mortality impacts, with slum residents bearing most of the burden.

items.title: Aligning machine and human visual representations across abstraction levels
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09631-6 Aligning foundation models with human judgments enables them to more accurately approximate human behaviour and uncertainty across various levels of visual abstraction, while additionally improving their generalization performance.

items.title: Photoinduced twist and untwist of moir superlattices
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09707-3 Femtosecond photoexcitation drives a coherent twistuntwist motion of the moir superlattice in 2 and 57 twisted WSe2/MoSe2 heterobilayers.

items.title: A universal speed limit for spreading of coherence
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09735-z Experiments reveal a speed limit for the spreading of spatial coherence during the formation of a weakly interacting BoseEinstein condensate.

items.title: Silicon solar cells with hybrid back contacts
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09681-w Silicon solar cells with hybrid interdigitated back contacts have a power conversion efficiency approaching 95% of the theoretical limit and a fill factor approaching 98% of the theoretical limit.

items.title: Rare genetic variants confer a high risk of ADHD and implicate neuronal biology
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09702-8 An analysis of rare genetic variants identifies three genesMAP1A, ANO8 and ANK2that have a role in attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and investigates the potential underlying biological mechanisms.

items.title: Synthesis of enantioenriched atropisomers by biocatalytic deracemization
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09738-w A new method for deracemization of atropisomers is described which leverages a P450 enzyme-mediated process involving bond rotation for enantioenrichment.

items.title: An ancient recombination desert is a speciation supergene in placental mammals
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09740-2 Deep learning methods identified a large and evolutionarily conserved X-linked low recombination region in placental mammals that serves as both a barrier to gene flow in hybridizing lineages and an accurate phylogenomic marker.

items.title: A molecularly impermeable polymer from two-dimensional polyaramids
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09674-9 Two-dimensional polyaramid polymers are synthesized to form nanofilms that exhibit the lowest gas permeability of any polymer by orders of magnitude, despite lacking crystallinity, enabling molecular-scale nanomechanical resonators and barrier materials.

items.title: Cytosolic acetyl-coenzyme A is a signalling metabolite to control mitophagy
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09745-x Acetyl-coenzyme A functions as a non-canonical signal to trigger mitophagy, and the acetyl-coenzyme ANLRX1 axis underlies the KRAS-inhibitor-induced mitophagy response and promotes drug resistance, providing a metabolic mechanism of KRAS inhibitor resistance.

items.title: GREGoR: accelerating genomics for rare diseases
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09613-8 The GREGoR consortium provides foundational resources and substrates for the future of rare disease genomics.

items.title: Viral NblA proteins negatively affect oceanic cyanobacterial photosynthesis
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09656-x Viral NblA accelerates the cyanophage infection cycle, directs degradation of the host phycobilisome and other proteins, and reduces host photosynthetic light-harvesting efficiency.

items.title: Radio burst from a stellar coronal mass ejection
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09715-3 An analogue to a type II burst from the early M dwarf StKM 1-1262 exhibits identical frequency, time and polarization properties to fundamental plasma emission from a solar type II burst.

items.title: iPEX enables micrometre-resolution deep spatial proteomics via tissue expansion
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09734-0 Isotropic tissue magnification is integrated with matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry imaging to enable untargeted spatial proteomics at micrometre resolution and with high protein identification rates in multiple tissue types.

items.title: Convergent genome evolution shaped the emergence of terrestrial animals
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09722-4 Comparisons of 154 genomes from 21 animal phyla and outgroups have been used to reconstruct ancestral adaptation to life on land across 11 distinct terrestrialization events, revealing strong evidence for convergent genomic evolution across the animal kingdom and recurring periods of terrestrial colonization.

items.title: SIGLEC12 mediates plasma membrane rupture during necroptotic cell death
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09741-1 CRISPRCas9-based genome-wide screening shows that SIGLEC12 mediates plasma membrane rupture in cells undergoing necroptosis, possibly through a human-specific mechanism, indicating its potential as a therapeutic target.

items.title: How much protein do you really need? What the science says
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03632-1 Fitness influencers promote super-high-protein diets, but studies show theres only so much the body can use.

items.title: Extreme rainfall poses the biggest risk to Mumbais most vulnerable people
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03453-2 An assessment of death rates in Indias coastal megacity of Mumbai reveals the impact of rain, high tides and flooding. Climate change will probably exacerbate the effects.

items.title: Global greenhouse-gas emissions are still rising: when will they peak?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03618-z Scientists say emissions could begin to decline in the next several years. What happens in China could determine when.

items.title: Can UK science really spawn a $1-trillion company?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03700-6 The British government wants the country to be home to a supersized tech firm within the next decade.

items.title: Mathematicians put AI model AlphaProof to the test
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03585-5 Mathematicians use computational tools to prove theorems. An AI model that is trained to use these tools might accelerate mathematical discovery.

items.title: Influential list of highly cited researchers now shuts out more scientists: heres why
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03691-4 Rule change weeds out many who co-author papers with others linked to suspicious practices.

items.title: Material system enhances superconducting qubits
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03644-x In the development of large-scale quantum processors, material improvements yield rapid progress because they can be readily translated to many devices and platforms. This work shows that, if they are built from tantalum and silicon, superconducting qubits can have millisecond-scale lifetimes and coherence times and reduced fabrication-related contamination.

items.title: Could humans live to 150? Why some researchers think were on the cusp of a major longevity breakthrough
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03524-4 Other scientists believe extending lifespan might be difficult but are pursuing therapies that aim to make us feel younger for longer.

items.title: Ultrathin films of a 2D polymer provide airtight seal
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03583-7 A polymer with a 2D molecular structure stacks into tightly packed layers  forming films of nanoscale thicknesses that are nearly impermeable to gases and moisture.

items.title: A guide to the Nature Index
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03527-1 A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.

items.title: How geopolitics is reshaping research: Data hint at shifting collaborations
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03025-4 Individual researchers and academic bodies are choosing not to work with other nations scientists amid geopolitical tensions. Is this affecting research output?

items.title: Hotcakes at the end times
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03666-5 Another satisfied customer.

items.title: Official statistics are vastly undercounting deaths from extreme weather
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03669-2 Research reveals that many more people lose their lives because of the effects of rainfall and flooding than are routinely accounted for.

items.title: Is ageing a disease? The debate that could reshape medicine
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03525-3 Classifying ageing as a disease might bring funding and other benefits, say some researchers, but others say this is fraught with ethical and regulatory implications.

items.title: To reform universities, first tackle global rankings
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03636-x Universities are in thrall to a rankings system that prioritizes narrow aspects of academic life. Three changes would give institutions the freedom to explore fresh ways of working.

items.title: Metabolite maps reveal spatial gradients in liver and intestinal tissue
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03457-y The abundances and fluxes of metabolite molecules were measured at cellular resolution in the mouse liver and small intestine. The levels of most metabolites showed considerable gradients in both organs. Furthermore, intake of the sugar fructose triggered depletion of ATP molecules at foci in the liver.

items.title: Chinese researchers reveal unexplored section of mysterious Arctic Ocean ridge
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03679-0 Oceanographers hope to find otherworldly ecosystems at hydrothermal vents on the seafloor.

items.title: It keeps me awake at night: machine-learning pioneer on AIs threat to humanity
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03686-1 Yoshua Bengio talks about his efforts to identify  and address  the risks posed by AI.

items.title: Three rising stars in ageing research
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03526-2 From Alzheimers to obesity, these researchers are tackling the most common age-related conditions.

items.title: Attosecond physics in optical near fields
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03093-3 Attosecond control of electrons in nanostructures requires resolving dynamics in the optical near field. Now, an experiment finds low-energy spectral stripes that track subcycle electron emission and allow the isolation of attosecond electron bursts.

items.title: Nickel-catalyzed arylative telomerization of isoprene
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64893-y Developing new transformations of bulky chemicals is an important approach to expand the horizons of current chemistry. Instead of traditional hydroarylation of dienes, the authors herein demonstrate a nickel-catalyzed arylative telomerization of isoprene with high chemo- and regioselectivities.

items.title: Catalytic asymmetric constructions of nitrogen, boron and carbon continuous stereogenic centers
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64905-x Although methods to enantioselectively assemble consecutive carbon stereocenters are abundant, establishing enriched continuous heteroatomic stereocenters remains a challenge. Here the authors report a protocol to synthesize continuous heteroatomic stereocenters from cyclic amine boranes and diazo compounds via asymmetric B-H insertion reaction.

items.title: Variation in surface protein expression leads to heterogeneous Trypanosoma cruzi populations during host cell infection
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64900-2 The authors assembled a high-resolution genome of Trypanosoma cruzi and, integrating transcriptomics, proteomics, and patient antibody responses, uncovered that this pathogen uses antigenic variation, suggesting strategies of infection persistence.

items.title: YTHDF2 regulates self non-coding RNA metabolism to control inflammation and tumorigenesis
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64898-7 RNA modifications influence gene regulation and disease. Here, the authors show that YTHDF2 recognizes m6A-modified U6 snRNA to prevent aberrant TLR3 activation to inhibit inflammation and skin cancer development.

items.title: Colistin resistance plasmids dually enhance bacterial virulence and antibiotic resistance via surface polysaccharide biosynthesis
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65412-9 In this work, authors show that colistin-resistance plasmids in Escherichia coli, via MCR-1 and a plasmid-encoded regulator, upregulate surface polysaccharide synthesis, enhancing antibiotic resistance and virulence and defining a mechanistic link between resistance and pathogenicity.

items.title: Heteroaromatic -stacking engineered near-infrared absorption for highly stable near-zero transmittance electrochromic window
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64955-1 Electrochromic materials have been used in thermal management systems though it is challenging due to limited NIR and long-term instability. Here the authors design an electrochromic organogel for stable electrochromic windows.

items.title: A composite motif in calcimembrin/C16orf74 dictates multimeric dephosphorylation by calcineurin
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64884-z C16orf74/ calcimembrin (CLMB), a lipidated microprotein with roles in cancer, targets the calcineurin phosphatase to membranes. Here, authors show how CLMB uses a composite motif to form multimeric complexes with calcineurin that are required for dephosphorylation.

items.title: Achieving electrochemical and mechanical stability in a lightweight titanium alloy
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64875-0 Seawater corrosion can impact the lifespan and reliability of metallic materials for marine applications. This work develops a titanium alloy exhibiting active passivation behavior that ensures its electrochemical and mechanical stability in seawater-like environments.

items.title: Artificial cytoskeletons in viscoelastic confinement
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02420-6 Artificial cytoskeletons in viscoelastic confinement

items.title: Electronic switching of topology in LaSbTe
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02396-3 This study shows that the nodal loop topology in LaSbxTe2x can be controlled by chemical substitution and electron doping. The reversible opening and closing of a gap larger than 400 meV in the nodal loop enables on-demand switching of topology.

items.title: Dual switches ignite tumour-specific mRNA therapeutics
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-02047-3 A two-step boost with tumour-specific lipids and untranslated regions ensures safe, precise and effective mRNA expression.

items.title: The governance evolution of nanotechnology from controversy to consensus
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-02035-7 The lively debate on nanotechnology that started 20 years ago spurred a collaborative effort between the private and public sectors that developed as the field was growing, leading to the creation of a regulatory framework that underpins todays successful implementation of nanotechnology. Emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence should take notice.

items.title: Spatially coherent oscillations in neural fields with inhibition and adaptation I: One-dimensional domains
items.summary: We study Hopf bifurcation of stationary activity bumps to localized, spatially coherent oscillations in a family of elementary neural field models involving nonlocal synaptic excitation and inhibition with Heaviside firing rate nonlinearity and local linear adaption, both with and without a localize [Phys. Rev. E] Published Tue Nov 11, 2025

items.title: Numerical simulation of a misaligned fluid drop in a rotating Hele-Shaw cell
authors: rio M. Coutinho and Jos A. Miranda
items.summary: In standard rotating Hele-Shaw cell flows, an initially circular fluid drop, surrounded by an outer fluid of negligible density and viscosity, is centered at the rotation axis of the cell. The interplay of centrifugal and surface tension forces leads to the emergence of intricate interfacial pattern [Phys. Rev. E] Published Tue Nov 11, 2025

items.title: Comprehensive echocardiogram evaluation with view primed vision language AI
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09850-x Comprehensive echocardiogram evaluation with view primed vision language AI

items.title: High performance tandem perovskite LEDs through interlayer photon recycling
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09865-4 High performance tandem perovskite LEDs through interlayer photon recycling

items.title: Partnerships between academia and industry must serve the public good
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03684-3 Partnerships between academia and industry must serve the public good

items.title: COP meetings must evolve to turn climate promises into action
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03682-5 COP meetings must evolve to turn climate promises into action

items.title: Insatiable squirrel ravages cherry blossoms for breakfast
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03456-z A mischievous red squirrel wreaks havoc on a woodland in search of snacks, and a record of life blooming on the volcanic island of Surtsey, in our weekly dip in Natures archives.

items.title: Kenyas black rhino revival is a story of hope for conservationists
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03685-2 Kenyas black rhino revival is a story of hope for conservationists

items.title: Academic freedom is key to the future of universities
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03683-4 Academic freedom is key to the future of universities

items.title: Be rational: chimp decision-making is guided by the strongest evidence
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03584-6 The ability to change your mind in response to better evidence is a hallmark of human cognition. Experiments now show that chimps are capable of rational thought too.

items.title: Failure is not an option for Africas newly launched medicines agency
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03668-3 The inequitable distribution of vaccines during the COVID-19 pandemic was the final proof of the need for more home-grown manufacturing and regulatory capacity across Africa.

items.title: Is HRT in menopause healthy? US label change triggers debate
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03687-0 The US FDA is removing serious health warnings from hormone replacement therapies. Scientists worry that more work is needed to get the message right.

items.title: For real climate action, empower women
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03630-3 In Belize, women are tackling climate change and biodiversity loss on the ground, but gender equity is needed in government, too  COP30 should address this.

items.title: Lessons from a long road to a first-author paper
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03348-2 Unlike my colleagues, I faced a five-year wait to publish my PhD project. Heres how I coped.

items.title: The computers that run on human brain cells
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03633-0 Move over silicon: scientists want to use neurons to make powerful computers with minuscule energy needs.

items.title: I have Einstein, Bohr and Feynman in my pocket
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03468-9 Grappling with difficulties in your career? Try asking an AI-powered advisory panel of experts, suggests Carsten Lund Pedersen.

items.title: Chinas new scientist visa is a serious bid for the worlds top talent
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03657-6 The country is easing migration for young researchers to boost its competitiveness in artificial intelligence, robotics and new materials.

items.title: Almost utopian: how protecting the environment is boosting the economy in Brazil
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03631-2 This bold approach could galvanize countries attending the COP30 summit.

items.title: Ethically sourced image data set encourages fairness in AI research
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03643-y AI systems rely on data that often lack diversity, perpetuate biases and violate intellectual-property rights. An ethical human-image data set addresses these problems.

items.title: Daily briefing: The Americas have lost their measles elimination status
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03705-1 A year-long outbreak of measles in Canada negates the countrys disease-free status. Plus, the benefits of being multilingual and computers that run on human brains.

items.title: How genetically encoded sensors have lit up neuroscience
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03639-8 Tools that track specific molecules in neurons have enabled researchers to probe previously unexplored aspects of neurobiology  although important caveats remain.

items.title: The beat of digital twins
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03085-3 The beat of digital twins

items.title: On knowledge and spectacle
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03088-0 On knowledge and spectacle

items.title: The prize at the end of the quantum tunnel
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03119-w The 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to John Clarke, Michel Devoret and John Martinis for the discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunnelling and energy quantisation in an electric circuit.

items.title: Field-tunable valley coupling in a dodecagonal semiconductor quasicrystal
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03080-8 Lacking translational symmetry, the momentum-space description of quasicrystals is distinct from that of fully crystalline materials. Now, a quasicrystal with two 2D layers links different momenta from the individual layers, allowing new excitons to form.

items.title: Lumen charge governs gated ion transport in -barrel nanopores
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 11 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-02052-6 By unifying data from engineered -barrel nanopores and supported by modelling, it is demonstrated that the lumen charge in a -barrel nanopore governs rectification and voltage-driven gating, with applications in computing using nanofluidic synapses.

authors: Matthias Veternik, Tobias Waldhtter, Lutz Schweikhard, Paul Scheier, and Elisabeth Gruber

authors: Isack Padilla, Aqil Sajjad, Babak N. Saif, and Saikat Guha
